awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a mmWave Software Defined Radio Network Testbed for Hybrid Measurement and Emulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The largely unregulated and unused millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency band is a potential home for new standards and protocols to increase network capacity (especially for a future 5G cellular communication standard). This project builds, deploys, and makes available to the research community a mmWave Software Defined Radio (SDR) network testbed.  A pressing need exists for flexible hardware platforms to: 
(1) Rapidly prototype new mmWave systems that consider not only point to point deployments, but also new multi-link mmWave network architectures;
(2) Allow for co-design of antennas, waveforms, and networking algorithms -- a requirement given the unique propagation characteristics of mmWave channel; and  
(3) Allow for hybrid measurement and emulation to allow real and virtual nodes to co-exist, which would enable scalable studies of new mmWave network architectures.
 
The mmWave SDR network testbed will be a flexible hardware platform that will enable researchers to rapidly prototype new mmWave systems.  Through intermediate frequency integration with the Echo Ridge Dynamic Spectrum Environment Emulator (DySE) channel emulator at Drexel and integration with commercial computational electromagnetic simulators, the testbed is expected to enable both over the air prototyping capabilities with commercial and custom antenna technologies as well as evaluation of emulated mmWave networks with customizable combinations of real and simulated nodes. The SDR testbed will consist of 5 Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP) X310 SDRs, enhanced with custom built millimeter transceivers designed and built in partnership with National Instruments. The instrument being developed will permit rapid prototyping of new mmWave systems that includes point-to-point deployments and multi-link mmWave network architecture, enabling researchers to test and verify new algorithms and protocols.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes:  

This project addressed key challenges in 5G cellular communications by advancing the use of millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequencies. These frequencies promise to alleviate the congestion of sub-6 GHz bands, enabling unprecedented network capacity and ultra-fast data rates. However, the deployment of mmWave technology is constrained by signal propagation challenges, such as rapid attenuation and sensitivity to obstacles. To address these challenges, we developed innovative hardware and software solutions, creating a flexible testbed for prototyping and evaluating mmWave communication systems.


Intellectual Merit:
The project developed a cutting-edge mmWave SDR Network Testbed capable of prototyping and evaluating mmWave systems and network architectures in real-world and simulated environments.  Key accomplishments include:

* Development of Conformal mmWave Antennas:  We designed and fabricated a beam-steerable, single-fed conformal antenna that enables 360-degree beam switching in the azimuth plane.  The antenna employs RF switches, ensuring superior performance in terms of insertion loss, power consumption, and beam-switching speed compared to conventional designs.  The antenna achieved robust beam-steering capabilities with reduced complexity, energy consumption, and cost.

* Testbed Integration and Evaluation:  We integrated the antennas into a software-defined radio (SDR) testbed, enabling over-the-air (OTA) and emulated testing of mmWave systems.  The testbed allows researchers to study the performance of mmWave transceivers, antennas, and network architectures under diverse real-world scenarios.These advancements provide a robust framework for studying and addressing critical challenges in mmWave communications, including signal attenuation, beamforming, and interference management.

* Integration of Machine Learning for Beam Selection: A low-complexity, machine-learning-driven algorithm was developed for real-time state selection in reconfigurable antennas at mmWave frequencies.  The system dynamically optimized beam directions based on environmental conditions, ensuring consistent performance in challenging propagation environments.

 

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of this work extend to various sectors, contributing to technological advancements and societal benefits:

* Advancing Wireless Connectivity:  The research supports the deployment of high-capacity 5G networks, enabling faster, more reliable connectivity for applications such as autonomous vehicles, smart cities, and augmented reality.  These outcomes have laid the foundation for the next generation of wireless communication systems, advancing both the theoretical understanding and practical implementation of mmWave technologies. The project’s contributions will influence future research and development, supporting the widespread adoption of 5G and beyond. 

* Educational Opportunities:  The testbed served as a resource for students, researchers, and industry collaborators to explore and prototype innovative wireless communication solutions.  Students worked on this project through the Drexel Students Tackling Advanced Research (STAR) program, Vertically Integrated Projects (VIP) program, and senior design program.  The testbed was also leveraged in a new customized graduate certificate program developed for Lockheed Martin.

* Technology Transfer: The testbed enabled research collaboration with industrial partners in testbed design, implementation, and application.  Partnership with Echo Ridge, LLC focused on wireless channel emulation and novel applications of the testbed.  Partnerships with Lockheed Martin applied the developed testbed for novel applications in multi-target tracking radar and generative AI and wireless waveform design.
